The facility periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating. The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained.

D.	Operating Procedures

Producers maintains written Operating Procedures of the covered process that address primary operations mandated by OSHA, EPA, Good Engineering Practice and manufacturers. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. Procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as currently accurate by management. The procedures are maintained current and accurate revising them as necessary by employee's suggestion, compliance audit, PHAs, Good Engineering practice, Pre- Startup Safety Review (PSSR) and implemented through Management of Change.

Covered Process Operating procedures are readily available to operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job task and maintain the covered process unit operating within its safe limits.

E.	Training

Producers has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating the covered process. New employees receive basic training in process operations if they are not already familiar with such operations. After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks. A performance review must be successfully completed during this training period. After the operator demonstrates adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they are allowed to work independently. In addition, all operators periodically rec

eive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted at least every 3 years, or more frequently upon request. All training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify and demonstrate skills.

F.	Contractors

Producers uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near Covered Process equipment, the facility has procedures in place to ensure that contractors:

1.	Perform their work in a safe manner
2.	Have the appropriate knowledge and skills
3.	Are aware of the hazards in their workplace
4.	Understand what they should do in the event of an emergency
5.	Understand and follow site safety rules
6.	Inform facility personnel of any hazard that they find during their work

This is accomplished by providing contractors with:

1.	A process overview
2.	Information about safety and health hazards
3.	Emergency response plan requirements
4.	Safe work practices before beginning work

In addition, Producer's Management will evaluate the contractor safety program and performance during the selection of a contractor. Facility personnel periodically monitor contractor performance with regard to their safety obligations.

G.	Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)
Producers conducts a PSSR for any new facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to see that safety features, procedures, personnel and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup before placing the equipment into service. This review provides one additional check that construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. Executive Summary

Accident Release Prevention and Response Policies
Scurry Midstream, LLC (Producers) owns and operates a natural gas processing plant, the White Wing Plant in Scurry County, Texas, that receives, stores, and transfers petroleum. The facility is designed to process natural gas, condensate, produced water, and natural gas liquids into end products that will be delivered to end markets.

Producers has a long-standing commitment to workers and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by efforts in accident prevention, such as training personnel, quality assurance, and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our process. Producers policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the facility, and notify the necessary outside agencies.
Description of the Station Source and Regulated Substance. 

The Producers White Wing Plant is located in Scurry County, Texas and operates a variety of processes to produce the following petroleum products:

1.	Stabilized Condensate
2.	Propane
3.	NGL
4.	Residue Gas

The received Y Grade and produced products can contain the following components:

a.	Methane
b.	Ethane
c.	Propane
d.	Butane
e.	Isobutane
f.	Pentane
g.	Isopentane
h.	Carbons larger than C5+

General Accident Release Prevention Program

A.	Employee Participation

Producers encourages employees to participate in all facets of accident prevention as follows:

1.	Updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information
2.	Performing necessary calculations for RMP
3.	Maintaining good engineering practices
4.	Employees have access to all information pertaining to the accident prevention program.

B.	Process Safety Information

H.	Mechanical Integrity

Producers has established practices and procedures for the safe operation of fixed, rotating and emergency shutdown equipment. The basic aspects of the program include, but are not limited to, the following:

1.	Conducting training
2.	Developing written procedures
3.	Performing inspections and tests
4.	Correcting identified deficiencies
5.	Applying quality assurance measures

In combination, these activities form a system to maintain the mechanical integrity of the process. Maintenance personnel receive training on:

1.	Overview of the process
2.	Safety and Health hazards
3.	Applicable maintenance procedures
4.	Emergency response plan
5.	Applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner.

Written procedures provide that work is performed in a consistent manner and serve as a basis for training. Inspections and tests are performed to help verify that equipment functions as intended and that equipment is within acceptable limits. If a deficiency is identified and the situation presents an immediate safety concern, the deficiency is corrected before placing the equipment back into service. A management of change team will review the use of equipment and determine what action is necessary.

An integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance. Producers incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps to determine that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and thee proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.

I.	Safe Work Practices

Producers has standing safe work practices as mandated by OSHA, EPA, Industrial Standards and Good Engineering Practice in place to help provide employee, public and process safety.

1.	Chemical properties and associated hazards
2.	Necessary Block Flow Diagrams of the process
3.	Maximum intended inventories
4.	Upper and Lower limits of process fixed and rotating equipment

Chemical specific information, including hazard and emergency response/exposure considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDS). For specific process areas, the facility has documented safety- related limits for specific process parameters such as temperatures, level and composition in the operators' procedures manual. The facility maintains the process within these limits by using process controls and monitoring instruments, trained personnel and protective instrument systems such as automated shutdown systems.

The facility also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of the process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressures, temperature and electrical ratings. This information, in combination with procedures and equipment operating history, provides a basis for inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to safety features in the process are not compromised.

C.	Process Hazard Analysis

Producers has a comprehensive program to identify and control hazards associated with the RMP covered process. This program systematically examines for potential hazards and puts controls in place to manage hazards. The team identifies, evaluates and makes recommendations to management of potential hazards identified. The team's findings are forwarded to Producer's Management for resolution. Universal Prevention Activities 

Producers' accident release prevention and response policies are applied to all RMP-covered processes. Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.

N.	Specialized Safety Features

Site-specific detection and control equipment (safety features) are deployed throughout the plant to:

1.	Contain/control a release
2.	Quickly detect a release, and
3.	Reduce the consequences of an RMP-regulated substance release

The following type of safety feature are used in the covered process:

Release Detection

1.	Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases 
2.	Automatic and manual valves to permit isolation of the process
3.	Automatic plant shutdown system to shut down all engines, plant utilities and automatically operate all automatic valves to their fail-safe position, diverting all incoming gas to the emergency flare.
4.	Curing or diking to contain liquids releases
5.	Redundant equipment and instrumentation
6.	Atmospheric relief devices

Release Mitigation

1.	Fire extinguishers only
2.	Trained emergency response personnel
3.	Personal protective equipment

O.	Five Year Accident History

Producer's White Wing Plant has had no RMP-regulated substance release during the past five years.

P.	Emergency Response Program Information

The plant maintains a written emergency action plan, which is in place to help protect employees and public safety as well as the environment. The plan identifies steps to be taken in case of an accidental release including: proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs.

1.	Determine that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards

Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information and procedures are updated to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are trained on the changes.

K.	Incident Investigation

Producers will promptly investigate all incidents related to a covered process that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in a fire/explosion, property damage, environmental loss or personal injury. The goal of each investigation will be to determine the facts and develop corrective action to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team will document its findings, develops recommendations to prevent future occurrences, and forward these results to facility management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations will be tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation will be documented and investigation reports will be retained for at least 5 years.

L.	Compliance Audits

At least every 3 years a Compliance Audit addressing OSHA, EPA, RMP and Good Engineering Practices is conducted by employees and management of Producers. This audit team develops findings that are forwarded to facility management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are completed. Final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.
